desc: f(0)=0 and f' increasing prove f(x)/x is increasing
solution:
\begin{soln}
  Clearly $g(x)$ is differentiable on $(0,\oo)$.
  Note that
  \[
    g'(x) = \frac{f'(x)x - f(x)}{x^2}
  .\]
  It suffices to show that $g'(x) \ge 0$ which is equivalent
  to showing $f'(x) \ge \frac{f(x)}{x}$. But note that by LMVT,
  \[
    \frac{f(x)}{x}=\frac{f(x)-f(0)}{x-0}=f'(c_x) \le f'(x)
  \]
  where $c_x \in (0,x)$ and the last inequality follows by
  monotonicity of $f'$. This finishes our proof.
\end{soln}

\begin{soln}
  Fix $0<x<y$ arbitrarily. By LMVT on $(0,x)$, we get
  \[
    \frac{f(x)-f(0)}{x-0}=f'(c_x)
  \]
  for some $c_x \in (0,x)$. Again, by LMVT on $(x,y)$, we get
  \[
    \frac{f(y)-f(x)}{y-x}=f'(d_{x,y})
  \]
  for some $d_{x,y}\in (x,y)$. Now, as $c_x < x < d_{x,y}$,
  we get $f'(c_x) \le f'(d_{x,y})$ which implies
  \[
    \frac{f(x)-f(0)}{x-0} \le \frac{f(y)-f(x)}{y-x}
  .\]
  By cross-multiplying terms and simplifying, we get
  \[
    \frac{f(y)}{y} \ge \frac{f(x)}{x}
  \]
  which finishes our proof.
\end{soln}

\begin{soln}
  From the condition that $f'$ is monotonically increasing,
  it is straightforward to prove that $f$ is convex. (Left
  as an exercise to the reader.)

  Fix $0 < x < y$ arbitrarily. By convexity,
  \[
    f\left(\left(\frac{x}{y}\right)\cdot y
    +\left(1-\frac{x}{y}\right)\cdot 0\right)
    \le \frac{x}{y}\cdot f(y)
    + \left(1 - \frac{x}{y}\right)f(0)
  \]
  which implies
  \[
    \frac{f(x)}{x}\le \frac{f(y)}{y},
  \]
  as desired.
\end{soln}
